title: Manolis Kalomiris
text:
Manolis Kalomiris (; December 14, 1883, <a href="Smyrna">Smyrna</a> – April 3, 1962, <a href="Athens">Athens</a>) was a <a href="Greece">Greek</a> <a href="Classical%20music">classical</a> composer. He was the founder of the Greek National School of Music.
Biography.
Born in Smyrna, he attended school in <a href="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> and studied <a href="piano">piano</a> and composition in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>. After working for a few years as a piano teacher in <a href="Kharkov">Kharkov</a> (then <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and now <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>) he settled in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>. An admirer of <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>, <a href="Nikolai%20Rimsky-Korsakov">Rimsky-Korsakoff</a>, <a href="Kostis%20Palamas">Kostis Palamas</a>, and <a href="Nikos%20Kazantzakis">Nikos Kazantzakis</a>, he set himself the life goal of establishing a Greek "national school" of music, based on the ideas of the <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n national composers, on western musical achievements and on modern Greek folk music, poetry and myth. He thus founded in 1919 the <a href="Hellenic%20Conservatory">Hellenic Conservatory</a> and in 1926 the <a href="National%20Conservatoire%20%28Greece%29">National Conservatoire</a>. At the same time, he served as the General Supervisor of <a href="military%20bands">military bands</a> in the country. He wrote three <a href="symphony">symphonies</a> and five <a href="opera">opera</a>s, one <a href="piano%20concerto">piano concerto</a> and one <a href="violin">violin</a> <a href="Concertino%20%28composition%29">concertino</a>, other symphonic works, <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a> and numerous songs and piano works. He held various public posts and was elected member of the <a href="Academy%20of%20Athens%20%28modern%29">Academy of Athens</a>.
A passionate composer, he has a post-romantic idiom characterised by rich harmonies and orchestrations, complex counterpoints, long eastern melodies, and the frequent use of Greek folk rhythms. A preoccupation with love and death transcends all five of his music dramas.
